RE: sprint delivers the next big thing??i agree with rob. i think if the phones (and mms is building traction in europe in handsets)
column2: this might be interesting. bottom line is will it a) help sell phones and b) bill enough time on the wcarriers networks?anyone remember the polariod photo sticker fad? low quality
column3: small in size. but kids totally dug that stuff. seems like every adolescent girl had that stuff at one point. and it never replaced or aimed to replace digital cameras or normal photographs. i don't think mms photos will be a substitute for other photography - developed at the local 1 hour joint or digital photos on your pc. i think it expands the market and forms a new category. the extent of the category size is the big question (will it be a fad or will it a sustained market). that's consumer behavior and marketing. but i don't think the technology adoption will follow a substitution of another product on the market (in this case
column4: digital photos or normal photos). europe's the one to watch - more teenagers have wireless phones and if the pricing and marketing is right
column5: they'll figure out what to do with it once the carriers how to figure out how to market it to them.-h>From: "Rob Shavell" <rob@mobiusvc.com>>To: "'Mike Masnick'" <mike@techdirt.com>>Cc: <fork@spamassassin.taint.org>>Subject: RE: sprint delivers the next big thing??>Date: Wed
column7: >>i will agree to disagree but i take your comments to heart.  my opinion is>only that this is one of the last frontiers of communications ('instant>show') that we cross easily (though you are right as rain on pricing).  i am>mildly amused at the level of skepticism and innatention it is getting.>>my premise is that the world will change in dramatic and unexpected ways>once there are a billion 'eye's' which can instantly share what they see>amongst each other.  that doesn't mean that people will stop talking on>their phones
column8: or that people will spend more time w/images than voice.  just>that it is fundamental.  from news to crime to privacy to dating to family>life to bloopers and practical jokes
column9: i believe there will be an explosion>of images unleashed specifically by cell phone integrated lenses because of>their utter ubiquity that dwarfs all pictures taken in the history of>photography by orders of magnitude and in short order. and yes
column10: changes>things 'big time'.>>rgds
column11: >rob>>>-----Original Message----->From: Mike Masnick [mailto:mike@techdirt.com]>Sent: Tuesday
column12: August 20
column13: 2002 11:58 PM>To: Rob Shavell>Cc: fork@spamassassin.taint.org>Subject: RE: sprint delivers the next big thing??>>>Not to keep harping on this
column15: Rob Shavell wrote:>>>content: who cares about content?  that no one can think of 'useful'>content>>is always the business persons mistake. the content is the users>>communications.  its anything and everything.  avg person could easily send>>half dozen pics to a dozen people a day.  mainly humorous i'd guess. who>>cares if content is trivial in nature. picture speaks a thousand words.>>This does nothing to answer my question.  I *do* care about content.  Hell
column16: >if I could be convinced that people would send stupid pics back and forth>all day
column17: I'd have a different opinion of this.  I just am not convinced>that they will (stupid or not).>>While a picture may be worth a thousand words (and this is the same>argument the guy who works for me made)
column18: how many people do you know who>communicate by pictures?  Sure
column19: it sounds nice to say that a picture is>such an efficient messaging mechanism
column20: but how often do you actually find>yourself drawing someone a picture to explain something?>>I don't buy it.>>For most messages
column21: text works fine and is the most efficient>mechanism.  For some messages
column22: pictures do the job
column23: but I would say not>nearly as often as words.  Why do you think Pictionary and Charades and>such are games?  Because images are usually not the most efficient way to>get a message across.>>>misc ramblings: i suppose you skeptical forkers would have said the same>>thing about '1 hour photo' processing.  trivial
column24: who needs it
column25: i get better>>resultion elswhere.  and yet
column26: it had great decentralizing impact - the>plant>>had to be downsized and pushed to the retail operation - the digital>camera
column27: >>and finally the integrated digital camera phone brings this cycle of>>decentralization in photography to a logical conclusion (which will put the>>photo giants to bed) and change the world in a meaningful way.  also
column28: SMS>>didn't take off because its easy
column29: it took off because it costs less.  its>>greatly ironic the carriers often trumpet the 'profitabilty' of their SMS>>traffic over others because of its ratio of cost to bandwidth.  in reality
column30: >>SMS cannibilizes the voice rev's they bought their networks to handle.>>Again
column31: this is the same argument my colleague made (along with "you just>don't understand kids today
column32: and they'll run with this").  I wasn't saying>that MMS wouldn't take off because it wasn't high quality or that it wasn't>easy.  I was saying that I couldn't see why people would use it in a way>that "changed the face of communications".>>I'm looking for the compelling reason (even if it's a stupid one) why>people would want to do this.  Sure
column33: if they integrate cameras into the>phone
column34: and the quality improves (even only marginally) I can certainly see>people taking pictures with their cameras and occasionally sending them to>other people.  But
column35: mostly
column36: I don't see what the benefit is to this over>sending them to someone's email address
column37: or putting together an online (or>offline) photoalbum.>>I don't think 1 hour photos are trivial.  People want to see their own pics>right away
column38: and the quality is plenty good enough for snapshots.  That's>one of the main reasons why digital cameras are catching on.  The instant>view part.  I'm guessing your argument is that people not only want>"instant view"
column39: but also "instant show".  Which is what this service>offers.  I'm not convinced that most people want "instant show".  I think>people like to package their pictures and show them.  That's why people put>together fancy albums
column40: and sit there and force you to go through them while>they explain every picture.  Sure
column41: occasionally "instant show" is nice
column42: but>it's just "nice" on occasion.  I still can't see how it becomes a integral>messaging method.>>What's the specific benefit of taking a picture and immediately sending it>from one phone to another?  There has to be *some* benefit
column43: even if it's>silly if people are going to flock to it.>>I'm searching... no one has given me a straight answer yet.>>The *only* really intriguing idea I've heard about things like MMS lately>are Dan Gillmor's assertion that one day in the near future some news event>will happen
column44: and a bunch of people will snap pictures with their mobile>phones
column45: from all different angles
column46: and those photos tell the real story of>what happened - before the press even gets there.>>Willing to be proven wrong
column47: >Mike>>PS If the wireless carriers continue to price these services as stupidly as>they currently are
column48: then MMS is *never* going to catch on.	0

column3: 21 Aug 2002 10:54:46 -0500>     From:        Chris Garrigues <cwg-dated-1030377287.06fa6d@DeepEddy.Com>>     Message-ID:  <1029945287.4797.TMDA@deepeddy.vircio.com>> >   | I can't reproduce this error.> > Ah
column4: I think I just found the cause
column5: nmh is broken (which is probably> obvious from my previous mail).> > The man page for pick (and how it always used to work) was that -list> would list messages matched.  -nolist would supress that.   If -sequence> is given the default is -nolist
column6: without -sequence the default is -list.> > That's all fine - but it appears now (which probably means I had never> used pick since I upgraded nmh last) that what counts is the order of> -list and -sequence - that is
column7: if -sequence comes after -list
column8: the -list> gets turned off (-sequence implies -nolist instead of just making -nolist> the default).> > An easy workaround for this is to make sure that -list is the last arg> given to pick
column9: so if I run ...> > delta$ pick +inbox -lbrace -lbrace -subject ftp -rbrace -rbrace  4852-4852 > -sequence mercury -list> 4852> > which is just as it should be.hmmm

column3: some of which generate far more dead    J> or marginal spots and others which are very expensive to    J> operate (due to backhaul transit considerations) or both.  This    J> software can be used as a tool to optimize the canopy coverage    J> and minimize the actual transit costs since the wireless is    J> tied into fiber at multiple points.So you only need to map a handful of metropolitan areas?    J> Or at least investors find this capability very sexy and    J> compellingAh ... now /that/ I will believe :)Don't mind me; I'm just getting even more cynical in my old age.   -- Gary Lawrence Murphy <garym@teledyn.com> TeleDynamics Communications Inc Business Advantage through Community Software : http://www.teledyn.com"Computers are useless. column1: ALSA (almost) made easyHi all
column2: I've decided at last to test the ALSA sound drivers. As usual the result isthat I've spent much more time repackaging the darn thing than actuallytesting the functionalities or trying to hear the great sound qualitypeople seem to think it outputs... but hey
column3: some of you will benefit fromthat
column4: right? ;-)I've got the whole thing working on a Valhalla system
column5: but the packagesshould easily install or at least recompile on Enigma
column6: Limbo/(null) andmaybe others
column7: who knows ;-)Here are quick instructions for those of you that wish to try it out :- Recompile the "alsa-driver" source rpm for your running kernel  (you can install the binary package if you're using the i686 2.4.18-10)- Install this "alsa-driver" package- Install the "alsa-libs" package- Install the "alsa-utils" packageNow go to this URL and find out what you need to change in your/etc/modules.conf file to replace the default OSS driver loading :http://www.alsa-project.org/alsa-doc/(very complete and very good documentation!)Hopefully you'll see that your card *is* supported ;-)Reboot
column8: or remove by hand your current sound modules (you'll probably needto stop many applications to free the sound resource...) "by hand" andinsert the new ones. If all is well you've got ALSA working! ("dmesg" tocheck is a good idea)
column9: you now just need to adjust the volume levels withe.g. aumix and alsamixer because everything is muted by default.With "aplay" you can already test files to see if you hear anything. Youcan also install the XMMS plugin (seems to make my XMMS segfault on exit...hmmm
column10: but maybe it's another plugin) to listen to your good ol' mp3files... that's it!It really isn't complicated
column11: and has never been from what I see. The onlything I disliked was to have to install from source... but as I can'timagine myself doing that ;-) I've repackaged everything cleanly. Even the/dev entries are included in the rpm package (and *not* created by an ugly%post script
column12: I insist!) and seamlessly integrate into the /etc/makedev.dstructure. There are also a few other noticeable differences with thedefault provided ALSA spec files
column13: for example I've split alsa-lib'sdevelopment files into an alsa-lib-devel package and included staticlibraries... there are others of course (oh yes
column14: the kernel version againstwhich the "alsa-driver" package is compiled gets neatly integrated in therpm release
column15: so does the architecture!).I'm open to any comments or suggestions about these packages!Download :http://ftp.freshrpms.net/pub/freshrpms/testing/alsa/Current spec files :http://freshrpms.net/builds/alsa-driver/alsa-driver.spechttp://freshrpms.net/builds/alsa-lib/alsa-lib.spechttp://freshrpms.net/builds/alsa-utils/alsa-utils.spec(All others
column16: patches etc. : http://freshrpms.net/builds/ )MatthiasPS: As an extra bonus
column17: I've also recompiled xine with alsa support! Simplyrun "xine -A alsa09" and off you go! It may even support 5.1 and S/PDIF ;-)-- Clean custom Red Hat Linux rpm packages : http://freshrpms.net/Red Hat Linux release 7.3 (Valhalla) running Linux kernel 2.4.18-10Load : 0.57 0.42 0.42
column18: AC on-line
column19: battery charging: 29% (1:55)_______________________________________________RPM-List mailing list <RPM-List@freshrpms.net>http://lists.freshrpms.net/mailman/listinfo/rpm-list	0

column1: [ILUG] PCTel modulesHello again. I tried all the suggestions for the PCTel driver and at the end of it
column2: everything still goes smoothly until I type "make" after I get the output from the ./configure. However
column3: there were a couple of things I noticed along the way. After typing * cp configs/kernel-2.4...config .config* make oldconfig* make depThe 2nd to last line I got back said that the modversions.h file was not updated. When I looked at this path to the modversions.h file
column4: it was 281 lines and every line started with a # mark. Is it the case that nothing is read on a line after a # mark (or am I just thinking of another language?) and so should I delete the # at certain places?Also
column5: when I was in the pctel directory and typed "make"
column6: I noticed that a different subdirectory is taken to a different modversions.h file. Inside this other file
column7: there's nothing at all. And so I moved the modversions.h file with 281 lines to the empty modversions.h file - and got a different reply after "make". The output after I moved the file over mostly looked like this:/usr/src/linux-2.4.18-3/linux/modversions.h:11:33: linux/modules/adb.ver: No such file or directory/usr/src/linux-2.4.18-3/linux/modversions.h:12:37: linux/modules/af_ax25.ver: No such file or directory/usr/src/linux-2.4.18-3/linux/modversions.h:13:36: linux/modules/af_ipx.ver: No such file or directoryThe odd lines being the path and the first half of the other lines are what's written after the # in the modversions.h file. Should there be a file at each of these (one at each of the 281 lines of the file) that I'd have to compile/make?It's taken plenty of elbow grease
column8: but I'm glad it hasn't gone smoothly
column9: it's a good learning experience. Again
column10: any help is appreciated. Thanks

column1: BUSINESS PARTNERSHIP(URGENT/CONFIDENTIAL)Mr.Vincent Nnaji
column2: Standard Trust Bank Ltd
column3: Lagos
column4: Nigeria. Dear Sir
column5: I am Mr.Vincent Nnaji
column6: Bank Manager of Standard Trust Bank
column7: Lagos
column8: Nigeria. I have urgent and very confidential business proposition for you. On January 6
column9: 1998 a Foreign Oil Consultant Foreign contractor with the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation Mr. James Herbert made a numbered time Fixed Deposit for twelve calendar months valued at US$20M ( Twenty Million United States Dollars) in my branch.Upon maturity I sent a routine notification to his forwarding address but got no reply. After a month we sent a reminder and finally we discovered from his contract employers the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation that Mr. James Herbert died from an automobile accident. On further investigation
column10: I found out that he died without making a WILL and all attempts to trace his next of kin was fruitless. I therefore made further investigation and discovered that Mr.James Herbert did not declare any next of kin or relations in all his official documents including his Bank Deposit paperwork in my Bank. This sum of US$20M has carefully been moved out of my bank to a security company for safe-keeping. No one will ever come forward to claim it. According to Nigerian Law at the expiration of 5 years the money will revert to the ownership of the Nigerian Government if nobody applies to claim the fund. Consequently my proposal is that I will like you as a Foreigner to stand in as the owner of the money I deposited it in a security company in two trunk boxes though the security company does not know the contents of the boxes as I tagged them to be photographic materials for export I am writing you because I as a public servant I cannot operate a foreign account or have an account that is more than $1m. I want to present you as the owner of the boxes in the security company so you can be able to claim them with the help of my attorney. All these are to make sure that the fruits of this old man's labour will not get into the hands of some corrupt government officials. This is simple. I will like you to provide immediately your full names and address so that the Attorney will prepare the necessary documents which will put you in place as the owner of the boxes. The money will be shared in the ratio of 70% for me and 25% for you and 5% will take care of all expenses. There is no risk at all as all the paperwork for this transaction will be done by the Attorney and this will guarantee the successful execution of this transaction. If you are interested
column11: please reply immediately via my private email address. Upon your response I shall then provide you with more details and relevant documents that will help you understand the transaction. Please observe with utmost confidentiality and be rest assured that this transaction would be most profitable for both of us because I shall require your assistance to invest my share in your country. Awaiting your urgent reply via my private email to indicate your interest. Thanks and Regards
column12: MR.VINCENT NNAJI.	1

column1: [ILUG] VPN implementationI need to setup a VPN between a few sites. From what I've read
column2: the thechoices come down (on the Linux side) to IPsec (using FreeSWAN) or CIPE.It seems that FreeSWAN is 'better'
column3: being an implementation of IPsec whichis a standard. However
column4: CIPE does the job as well for Linux clients and issomewhat simpler to setup. The problem is that it's not a pure Linux situation - a couple of the sitesrun OS-X. I'm pretty sure that I'll be able to find an implementation ofIPsec for OS-X
column5: but I think CIPE is Linux only.So
column6: the question is for those of you have have implemented BOTH - is there asignificant difference in setup time and hassle between CIPE and FreeSWAN ?If CIPE is going to be much easier than dealing with FreeSWAN (and whateveron the OS-X sites) then I'll simply get a Linux box for each of the remotesites - with the low price of hardware
column7: it doesn't take much more complexityin software to make buying hardware to use simpler software economic.Niall-- Irish Linux Users' Group: ilug@linux.iehttp://www.linux.ie/mailman/listinfo/ilug for (un)subscription information.List maintainer: listmaster@linux.ie	0

column1: Free Excerpt;  Baby Makers
column2: Loser Choosers
column3: & Welfare Abusers...Images of My America!                         ForewordAfter thirty?three years of being a black man living in "Ghetto America
column4: an environment notorious for danger, crime, and poverty, I have made startling discoveries involving young African?American men and women who comprise what I have come to define as the Black Generation X". I have become aware that there is no formal distinction separating young African?Americans from the general definition of "Generation X". Aside from it being regarded as the generation that followed "Baby Boomers"
column5: it's important to point out there is no root definition for this term as well. Since the theme of this work is centered on identifying the realities and misconceptions of young African?American culture
column6: I have chosen a definition that incorporates all of the components that were part of my birth
column7: childhood
column8: and young adult life. Taken from a web site entitled "Generation X"
column9: created and maintained by the Colorado College
column10: the definition is as follows:   "We are a group of people born between 1961 and 1981. We are individuals who live for the 'here and now'
column11: like to experiment
column12: and who require immediate results. We are typically selfish
column13: and cynical
column14: and depend a lot on our parents. We question authority
column15: and feel like we carry the burden of the previous generations. It's that simple. It seems we have come to be called "Xer's" simply because we represent something negative to our elders. We may be the one thing all of the generations that precede us have in common
column16: that is the ability to speak assuredly about our shortcomings. Of course
column17: they overlook the fact that we are their responsibility
column18: or actually their fault. Our generation will be called upon to look after our parents knowing they failed to look after us. Intergenerational justice failed somewhere along the way and it will be our task to either rectify it or make it worse.""We are a group of individuals who grew up with no one at home after school. It appears we have little hope for the future. No jobs
column19: no homes
column20: and basically no money are almost expected of us. These bleak prospects
column21: along with the fact that we will be forced to support the largest amount of senior citizens ever
column22: do not provide much hope. Some believe that these blockades will be too much for us to handle and we will for the most part fail at life
column23: but many see our individualism and resourcefulness that has been built up through our childhood
column24: as our saviors. We will soon discover who is right and who is wrong." This definition is important because it demonstrates the widely held belief that Generation X is comprised of one core group of American citizens. It over generalizes the similarities it expresses
column25: and applies them to all those who were born within the corresponding years. When in fact these "similarities" speak primarily to only "white" issues and concerns. For instance
column26: "they" say "we" depend a lot on our parents
column27: but in ghetto America "we" could only depend on one our mothers! "They" also say
column28: " . . .we feel like we carry the burden of previous generations
column29: and  . . . we will be forced to support the largest amount of senior citizens ever." In ghetto America
column30: no one ever gives these issues any thought because survival is in the here and now
column31: and is all "we" have time for. I have known for many years that the differences that separate Generation Xer's black and white occupants would eventually be identified. I never knew I would be the one doing it. Extracting the "Black" from "Generation X" and categorizing it for its own sake is a necessary and important contingency. Without doing so
column32: the social ills that plague Ghetto America would be lost within the generalities that are explained away as part of a collective American identity.There are many hidden truths that exist in black America today. "White America" charges that we spend our time collecting welfare
column33: refusing to vote
column34: reading elementary styled books
column35: watching music videos
column36: day dreaming of becoming rappers
column37: basketball players
column38: selling drugs
column39: and making babies. Much of this is supported in Marlon Riggs's documentary entitled "Ethnic Notions." When African Americans are mentioned
column40: whites typically envision an image that is strikingly similar to the one that graces the cover of this book. A reality that I confirmed while watching "Roger & Me
column41: another documentary written, and directed by Michael Moore. Sadly, many of us have begun to validate this skewed image, while others bend over backwards in an attempt to pretend we do nothing of the kind, only to be contradicted and embarrassed when presented with the daily programming line up for B.E.T. (Black Entertainment Television). Many of us fail to realize, that whatever embarrassment or shame the ex posed truth may reveal, should be taken as an opportunity to improve, empower, enlighten, and ultimately change anyone who is guilty of perpetrating this kind of behavior.Regarding Black Women: I have known many in my life and although each has had unique attitudes and personalities, I began to notice the majority of them shared the same collective mentality toward black men as a whole-that black men owed them something, and are required to provide and fulfill what was missing from their lives, be it emotional, physical, or economical. Normally that type of assertion would not warrant opposition from me, so long as a reciprocal attitude was extended. In most cases, it has not been. It's funny though, looking back, I am surprised I never paid any attention to the beliefs and attitudes that different black women subscribe to, or the various schools of thought they possessed. Many have placed strict demands and presumptions on the African?American male, some fair and some unfair. Much of what the public believes and understands about the black female's social structure is often filtered by others in the black community who believe these inaccurate and frequently positive representations will somehow change the reality that is. What originally sparked my attention was an observation I stumbled upon while skimming through and reading books related to black male and female interaction. I noticed virtually all of the books I read in the genre depict an inaccurate and misleading concentration on the affluent African?American perspective. These stories and commentaries tend to suggest that all African?Americans thrive on a middle?to?upper class professional level. They relay stories of relationship problems with Huxtable?like" bachelors and bachelorettes whose only concern is why the other has not confessed his or her love. As I read these stories I couldn't help but become irritated by the blatant omission of the prevailing majority of blue collar or "working class" African?Americans. Although there are those in the black community that can identify with the "Huxtable?like" dynamic
column42: unfortunately
column43: they are few and far between. The majority of stories I have read seem to be geared toward fantasizing and romanticizing the oppressive state of affairs that have plagued Black America. The black authors who have written these books fear the potential backlash awaiting anyone who would dare air out our "dirty laundry". The fact is
column44: truth should never be stifled by fear of any kind. I recently had a candid conversation with some very dear female friends who stated that although they fully acknowledge the terrible state of affairs many of our women are currently drowning in
column45: they felt that publicizing their predicament would be viewed as a form of betrayal. As our discussion intensified
column46: I reminded them that the only way change can be effected is by increasing public awareness that change is needed
column47: and oftentimes
column48: not exposing the truth can be more crippling than the truth itself. The purpose of my book is in essence an attempt to change the self?destructive thinking and self?imprisoning behavior that "black male and female generation X" have been subscribing to. While discussing this with my friend
column49: she suggested I simplify my writing style so my potential black readers could better understand what I'm attempting to convey. Acknowledging the real possibility of my message being misunderstood
column50: I suggest to those readers that if they want to fully appreciate the finer points of this narrative-to grab a dictionary. (Don't feel bad-there were several times I had to as well!)Regarding Black Men: An overwhelming number of us have become preoccupied with being cool
column51: buying sports wear
column52: driving expensive cars
column53: wearing gold or platinum jewelry
column54: and often without legitimate personal wealth and while living under the most deplorable conditions! I have chosen to address this rarely acknowledged side of African?American culture because I have lived it. I have seen the chaos and futility that exists on this level. It is a world of ignorance
column55: selfishness
column56: pre?occupation
column57: and idiocy.In my world there are people who applaud a lack of education
column58: who brag about having served time in U.S. penitentiaries
column59: the types of guns they carry
column60: dope peddling
column61: and chasing women. They champion the notion of having children without any regard to the poor environment many of them currently inhabit. In this world
column62: wearing expensive clothes and carrying fancy handbags is mandatory even if it means spending their last dollar in order to look like they've got a million. It's a world where children dress in over?priced sports wear
column63: mimicking and idolizing whatever popular athlete or rapper is currently in the public eye. Thinking
column64: such as the belief that fancy clothes are what define one's self?worth
column65: and the possible corruption this thinking breeds
column66: seems to not be an important concern for black mothers. It may come as a shock to know that most African?Americans feel that those who don't have the same
column67: if not better
column68: material possessions
column70: referring to them as being corny
column71: lame
column72: or broke. Even our "male rapper" entertainers promote backward priorities-nothing else matters as long as you look good. "The Big Tymers"
column73: a popular rap duo
column74: have a song called "I'm Still Fly"
column75: shown in heavy rotation on B.E.T. and played regularly on black radio stations throughout the country. ("Fly" is ghetto vernacular for well dressed
column76: also used to describe a female's beauty). Its signature verse asserts:"I got gator boots with a pimped out GucciSuit
column77: can't pay my rent cause all my money'sspent
column78: but that's O.K. cause I'm still fly."Worse yet
column79: in the song "Grinding"
column80: the popular duo "Eclipse" glorifies the selling of illegal drugs in inner city neighborhoods as children play and dance throughout the entire video. (The term "grinding" is ghetto vernacular for the selling of illegal drugs) The fact that this song and video is also shown in heavy rotation on B.E.T. is further evidence that our world is in utter turmoil. Some of the key lyrics to this song are "grindingyou know what I keep in the lining" (the area in their coats where they hide illegal drugs) and"Patty cake Patty cake I'm the bakers manI bake them cakes as fast as I canand you can tell cause of how my bread stack upand I disguise it as rap so the feds backup"In this verse
column81: the group refers to the process of cooking cocaine and its transformation into cocaine base or crack. When created it is compressed into the form of a large cookie with the average diameter being the size of a typical cake. (hence the term "cake" or sometimes "pie") Unfortunately for the rap genre
column82: this song seems to strengthen the long standing argument posed by most whites that rap music is nothing more than an entertainment medium catering to violent drug offenders
column83: who want and do nothing more than carry guns and break the law. The negative references I've identified have become an integral part of the urban African?American existence. This mutated reality is ridiculous and unacceptable. This ideology should not be permitted to continue any longer than it already has. There is an overwhelming part of the African?American community that is aware of this crippling mentality. There are also many that are unaware and unfortunately
column84: more that do not even care. Those of us who are in the know have a responsibility to educate and enlighten those of us who are not aware of the negative behavior being perpetrated daily. Whether because of habit or misguided values
column85: this type of ideology is cyclical and thrives off of ignorance. It should be apparent to us all that we cannot wait for some other race to come and save us. We must save ourselves! I am well aware that many of you are probably furious by now
column86: and are thinking
column87: what right do I have to express the opinions I have thus far
column88: as well as those I have al luded too. I have chosen to chronicle my experiences because of the diversity and seriousness of their content. There is far too much negativity thriving within our culture. There must be acknowledgment and accountability for the truth
column89: whether good or bad. I am aware that not all of "us" have succumbed to the crippling mentality that is rampant in our community
column90: and I have chosen to concentrate on individuals who have had a profound impact on my life. Any similarities and generalizations I illustrate are directed solely toward individuals in the black community who share the collective negative thinking and behavior that will hereafter be identified. Additionally
column91: throughout this book I will refer to African?Americans in four different ways; the first being "African?Americans"
column92: denoting our status as citizens in the United States; secondly
column94: a reference that identifies and defines our differences and struggles in this country; third
column95: as "Niggas
column96: a term which is often misunderstood and should not be confused with Nigger". The term "nigga" has become an accepted form of reference among young black males used to express friendship (hence the term "My Nigga") as well as a blanket reference when speaking to
column97: of
column98: or about other black males in a non?personal manner. I felt it necessary to make this distinction because many of the experiences I will refer to mandate the use of the term to effectively communicate the attitude and mood that existed during the time each story took place; and fourth
column99: as "Ghetto"
column100: this term is largely intended as an internal reference commonly understood by blacks as a means to define the  less polished members of our community.  It is important to note that the use of either term has no negative connotation and is therefore not to be associated with any feeling as such. My commentary is based on real?life situations
column101: both good and bad
column102: and how one African?American man was affected by them. To that end
column103: I feel it is necessary to acknowledge that my intention is not to condemn the individuals I have encountered. Despite the negativity they have displayed
column104: I only want to make them aware that the selfish and self debasing attitudes they subscribed to
column106: has caused them to become their own worst enemy.In the case of the black female's negative and limited perspective toward black men
column108: and subconsciously themselves
column109: I submit that this mentality is perhaps single?handedly responsible for the lack of success
column110: happiness
column111: and quality of life that is at the center of every African?American woman's fantasy quest. It is also important to note that the selfish and negative attitudes at the core of the tension that exists between black women and men
column112: has been deliberately created by "White America". For example
column113: much of the existing resentment between black women and men can be traced as far back as slavery on up to present day. Many past issues have taken on new identities and have re?emerged in the form of corporate acceptance of black women and the corporate exclusion of black men. The resulting economic independence that some black women now enjoy has caused them to challenge and judge the black man for his absence within corporate America
column114: without realizing and ackno wledging that this absence is by design. There are other "core" issues that have been passed down and nurtured from generation to generation
column115: such as color barriers
column116: light skin versus dark skin
column117: good hair versus bad hair
column118: loyalty
column119: devotion
column120: and economic status. Believe it or not
column121: there was once a time when black women refused to date a black man if he didn't sell drugs or was not "thugged out". (a term for being rough or hoodlum-like) The reasoning behind it being that the "thug
column122: and drug dealer" lifestyle was synonymous with financial independence. These issues
column123: among others
column124: relate directly to the confused mentality that exists within our internal society. Sadly that "confused mentality" is responsible for much of the neglect the African American "ghetto" community receives at the hands of our more affluent brethren. Who have locked it away in the basement
column125: and seems to be more concerned with convincing the rest of the world that "ghetto America does not exist. Furthermore
column126: the lack of acknowledgement of which I speak should not be confused with the impoverished masses of the African American community.  Their plight is a well-known reality
column127: but in many cases much of ghetto America falls under that same umbrella. Be advised: this book is not a colorful or lighthearted look into "Black America".  Rather it should be viewed as a legitimate tool for identifying and changing the backward thinking that so many young African Americans (including myself) have come to perpetuate. Moreover
column128: that "backward thinking" is the main  cause of our inability to strive for a common goal. An outcome that must be met; and can only be met
column134: self and mutual respect.************************************************************* To read More go to www.blackrealitypublishing.comTo Unsubscribe: send mail to majordomo@FreeBSD.orgwith "unsubscribe freebsd-ports" in the body of the message	1

column1: Re: Goodbye Global WarmingThanks for the link - I'm fascinated by archaeology as well.----- Original Message -----From: "James Rogers" <jamesr@best.com>To: <fork@spamassassin.taint.org>Sent: Monday
column2: September 23
column3: 2002 2:48 PMSubject: Re: Goodbye Global WarmingI've seen articles on this type of stuff passing through various forumsfor several years.  I've always found archaeology interesting for noparticular reason.  Here is a recent article from U.S. News that Iactually still have in the dank recesses of my virtual repository.-James Rogers jamesr@best.com--------------------------------------------http://www.usnews.com/usnews/issue/020916/misc/16meltdown.htmDefrosting the pastAncient human and animal remains are melting out of glaciers
column4: a bountyof a warming worldBY ALEX MARKELSAs he hiked near Colorado's Continental Divide in the summer of 2001
column5: EdKnapp noticed a strange shape jutting from a melting ice field at 13
column6: 000feet. "It looked like a bison skull
column7: the building contractor andamateur archaeologist recalls. I thought
column8: 'That's strange. Bison don'tlive this high up.' "Knapp brought the skull to the Denver Museum of Nature and Science
column9: where scientists last month announced that it was indeed from abisonone that died about 340 years ago. "This was an extraordinarydiscovery
column10: says Russ Graham, the museum's chief curator, adding that itcould alter notions of the mountain environment centuries ago. There'sprobably a lot more like it yet to be found."And not just bison. Colorado isn't the only place where glaciers andsnowfields are melting. Decades of unusual warmth in regions from Peruto Alaskaa trend some think is linked to emissions from cars andindustryhave shrunk or thawed many of the world's 70
column11: 000 glaciers. Asthe ice recedes
column12: a treasure-trove of human and animal artifacts isemerging
column13: extraordinarily well preserved after centuries in the deepfreeze. The fabrics
column14: wood
column15: bone
column16: and DNA-rich tissue found on the muckyfringes of the ice are revising scientists' understanding of ourpredecessors' health
column17: habits
column18: and technology
column19: and the prey they pursued."It's mind-boggling how many different fields are being advanced throughstudying these remains
column20: says Johan Reinhard, a high-altitudearchaeologist and explorer-in-residence at the National GeographicSociety. Rare, spectacular finds like the frozen mummies he discoveredin the Andes of Peru in the 1990s and the legendary 5,300-year-old IceMan
column21: found at the edge of a receding glacier in the Alps in 1991, haveoffered time capsules of cultural and biological information. Now, asthe ice continues to retreat, it is yielding not just occasionaltreasures but long records of humans and animals in the high mountains.Vanishing act. The trick is finding such specimens before MotherNatureand looterstake them first. Once uncovered, frozen remains candeteriorate within hours or be gnawed by animals. Moreover, they'reoften so well preserved when they emerge that people who come upon themdon't even realize they're ancient.That was the case when three men hunting sheep near a high glacier inBritish Columbia, Canada, three years ago saw what they thought was adead animal. It looked a little like sealskin buried in the ice
column22: recalls Warren Ward, a teacher from nearby Nelson. But when I lookedcloser I could see leather fringe from a coat and finger bones."Figuring they had found the remains of another hunter
column23: or perhaps a furtrapper
column24: the men stowed a flint knife and other artifacts in a Zip-Locbag and delivered them to local officials. Archaeologists later exhumedthe fallen hunter's body
column25: along with a woven hat
column26: fur clothing
column27: and whatseemed to be a medicine bag. Carbon dating revealed that the hunterlived about 550 years ago. Dubbed Kwaday Dan Ts'inchi
column28: or Long AgoPerson Found
column29: by people of the Champagne and Aishihik First Nations (whomay be his direct descendants)
column30: he is perhaps the best-preserved humanfrom the period ever found in North America.Other findings from melting ice in the neighboring Yukon region couldexplain what that long-ago person was doing in the mountains in thefirst place. "Before this there was no archaeological record of peopleliving here
column31: says Greg Hare, a Yukon government archaeologist. Now wesee that this area was very much part of people's seasonal activities."Like Ward's discovery
column32: the search began by chance
column33: when Kristin Benedekcaught a whiff of what smelled like a barnyard as she and her husband
column34: Gerry Kuzyk
column35: hunted sheep at 6
column36: 000 feet in the mountains of the southYukon. They followed the scent to a melting patch of ice covered incaribou dung. "It was really odd
column37: because I knew there hadn't beencaribou in the area for at least 100 years
column38: recalls Kuzyk, then awildlife biologist with the Yukon government.Caribou cake. Returning a week later, he found what looked like apencil with string wrapped around it." It turned out to be a4
column39: 300-year-old atlatl
column40: or spear thrower. Further investigation of theice patchand scores of others around the regionrevealed icy layercakes filled with caribou remains and human detritus chronicling 7
column41: 800years of changing hunting practices.Scientists now believe ancient caribou and other animals flocked to theice each summer to cool down and escape swarming mosquitoes and flies.Hunters followed the game. They returned for centuries and discardedsome equipment in the ice. "We've got people hunting with throwing dartsup until 1
column42: 200 years ago
column43: says Hare, who now oversees the researchproject. Then we see the first appearance of the bow and arrow about1
column44: 300 years ago. And by 1
column45: 200 years ago
column46: there's no more throwingdarts."Now scientists are trying to make the search less a matter of luck. Theyare developing sophisticated computer models that combine data on whereglaciers are melting fastest and where humans and animals are known tohave migrated to pinpoint the best places to search in Alaska's Wrangelland St. Elias mountain rangesthe United States' most glaciatedterrainand in the Andes. Johan Reinhard thinks the fast- thawingEuropean Alps could also deliver more findings

column4: but you've just gotten to the crux of thesituation.  There's good design and bad design. There's good testing and bad testing.  The problemis
column5: anyone can design a good Web form
column6: but nobodydoes.  I think "best practices" hasn't caught upon main street Web enablement yet.  There's somereally great packages on how to do this stuff andin fact the usability people knew that Web forms neededto be fixed 5 years ago
column7: so that's why we got XFormsand  XHTML.  You can shoot yourself in the foot andpeople usually do.  What the problem is
column8: they don'teven recognize that they're gimpy--ever.  They justkeeping trundling along making a mess of everythingassured in their job security that they can buildWeb forms without even caring if they can beused or not beyond their test machine.If you had a piece of software and a security warningcame out 5 years ago on it
column9: would you run that software?Wouldn't you have patched or upgraded something so fundamentallybroken 4 years and 11 months ago?  What I want to knowis why would someone use Web forms best practices from5 years ago?  I mean you can get a college degree in thattime.  Imagine if the next version of Microsoft Windowsor Red Hat Linux forced you to use a tiled windowmanager?  Sure

column1: SunWell
column2: it looks like Sun are going ahead withtheir ubiquitous computing plans without Mithril. GregReuters Market News  Sun Micro Outlines Roadmap for Managing Networks   Friday September 20
column3: 5:00 am ET   By Peter Henderson   SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Computer maker Sun Microsystems Inc. on Thursday  said it would create in a few years a network environment that will be as  straightforward to handle as a single machine
column4: a strategy it calls N1.  It laid out a road map for a new layer of intelligent software and systems that will meld  unwieldy networks into easy-to-use systems
column5: a goal similar to those of most rivals  making computers which manage networks.   EMC Corp. announced this week software aimed at allowing users to manage storage  resources as a pool. Hewlett-Packard Co has a Utility Data Center
column6: designed for  broader management. International Business Machines Corp's project eLiza is working  to make computers "self-healing" when systems break.  "Applications still have to run zeroes and ones on some computing engine but the  whole idea behind N1 is you stop thinking about that. You don't think about what box  it is running on
column7: Sun Vice President Steve MacKay, head of the N1 program, said in an  interview on the sidelines of a Sun user conference.   Many industry executives see computer power eventually being sold like power or  water, as a utility that can be turned on or off, in whatever volume one wants whenever  needed.   For that to happen computers must be tied together seamlessly, rather than cobbling  them together with tenuous links, as most networks do today, experts say. There are  still major barriers, though, such as communications standards for machines from  different vendors to interoperate closely.   Sun promised to deliver a virtualization engine" that would let administrators look at  their entire network as a pool by the end of the year. Network administrators today  often have no automatic system to report what is in the network.   "It'll tell you what you have and how it is laid out
column8:
promised MacKay The second stage, beginning in 2003, would allow users to identify a service, such as online banking, and allocate resources for them with a few clicks, Sun said. Finally, in 2004, Sun's software should allow networks to change uses of resources on the fly in response to changing needs, such as a bank assuring quicker online response time for priority users, the company said. 0 [ILUG] Best Replica Goods - Best Prices*** FREE BONUS OFFER - SEE BELOW ***We can supply TOP QUALITY, VIRTUALLY IDENTICAL REPLICAS of just about anything - from watches to wallets, from lighters to lingerie, clothing, accessories, even electrical goods. column1: Invite: Content Management Summit
column2: Oct. 10th New York City<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"><html><head>  <title>This email is being sent to zzzz@jmason.org. To unsubscribe pleasevisit http://www.venturereporter.net/myaccount/ . If you ever have a problemremoving or changing your email subscriptions on our newsletters
column3: or gettingin touch with us
column4: please don't hesitate to email support@venturereporter.netand a human will get in touch with you immediately. Venture Reporter 307West 36th Street
column5: 10th Floor New York
column6: New York 10018 Phoe: 646.473.2222The online content business.
column7: sans-serif"><font size="2">Dear Friends
column8: The online content business is doing fantastic.
column9: sans-serif"><font size="2">Sound crazy? Perhaps.  With advertising
column10: online and off
column11: taking it on the chinfor the past two years
column12: online content sites have been shutting down
column13: layingoff staff and pulling back on their offerings.
column14: sans-serif"><font size="2">However
column15: this horrible environmenthas resulted in an undeniable trend:  content businesses are challengingpeople to pay for content.  Finally
column16: after five years of free
column17: people are beginning to understand that online
column18: as in the realworld
column19: you get what you pay for and they are taking out their credit cards. U.S.  consumers spent $675 million on paid online content lastyear
column20: a 92 percent increase over 2000 spending levels
column21: according to OnlinePublishers Association
column22: and that figure is expected to increase exponentiallythis year. Look at these success stories:
column23: sans-serif"><font size="2">New York Times Digital has been steadily increasing its paid content services over the last year
column24: and registered a 16 percent increase in its total revenues for the latest quarter.
column25: sans-serif"><font size="2">TheStreet.com brought over $3 million in subscriptions last quarter
column26: an increase of almost 50 percent over the year-ago quarter.
column27: sans-serif">ConsumerReports.com will reach over a million paying subscribers by the end of this year.
column28: sans-serif"><font size="2">RealNetworks' consumer multi-media subscription service has more than 750
column29: 000 subscribers
column30: bringing in $17.8 million in the last quarter.
column31: sans-serif"><font size="2">The Wall Street Journal Onlineadded over 6
column32: 000 new paying customers last quarter
column33: bringing its subscriberbase to 646
column34: 000.
column35: sans-serif"><font size="2">FT.com has signed up 17
column36: 000 subscribers in three months since it launched its premium site in May.
column37: sans-serif">In recognition of this trend we're hosting the third installation of our innovative <a class="" href="http://www.cmsummit.com">Content Management Summit on October 10
column38: 2002. The event charts the changes in the content industry from free to paid subscription services
column39: and the technologies that are enabling the management and monetizing of content.
column40: sans-serif">Our previous Content Management Summit (aka Digital Rights Summit) on October 18 last year in New York City and January 29 in Los Angeles were unqualified successes.

column42: taking place in New York at the Millennium Broadway on October 10

column3: I assume you're going to report this to the nmh folks?Yes
column4: I will
column5: sometime
column6: after I look at the nmh sources and see whatthey have managed to break
column7: and why.But we really want exmh to operate with all the versions of nmh thatexist
column8: don't we?   The patch to have exmh do the right thing
column9: whether thisbug exists
column10: or not
column11: is trivial
column12: so I'd suggest including it.Patch follows ...I have no idea why the sequences were being added after the message listbefore
column13: not that it should make any difference to nmh (or MH).   But sinceI stopped doing that
column14: the variable "msgs" isn't really needed any more
column15: rather than assigning $pick(msgs) to msgs
column16: and then using $msgs the codecould just use $pick(msgs) where $msgs is now used.   This is just afrill though
column17: so I didn't change that.  kre--- pick.tclFri Aug 23 16:28:14 2002+++ /usr/local/lib/exmh-2.5/pick.tclSat Aug 24 18:14:44 2002@@ -128
column19: 7 @@ } proc Pick_It {} {     global pick exmh-    set cmd [list exec pick +$exmh(folder) -list]+    set cmd [list exec pick +$exmh(folder)]     set inpane 0     set hadpane 0     for {set pane 1} {$pane <= $pick(panes)} {incr pane} {@@ -175
column21: 9 @@     }     set msgs $pick(msgs)     foreach s $pick(sequence) {-lappend msgs -sequence $s+lappend cmd -sequence $s     }+    lappend cmd -list      Exmh_Debug Pick_It $cmd $msgs     busy PickInner $cmd $msgs_______________________________________________Exmh-workers mailing listExmh-workers@redhat.comhttps://listman.redhat.com/mailman/listinfo/exmh-workers	0

column1: Re: Hanson's Sept 11 message in the National ReviewIn a message dated 9/19/2002 7:46:37 AM
column2: chuck@topsail.org writes:>That means *you* can't say anything may not be FoRKed or printed or >whatever. You have the choice to ignore itThat's not what the First Amendment says at all. It says that Congress cannot say what can't be FoRKed. FoRK can establish any rules it wants. Similarly
column3: The New York Times gets to choose what news IT thinks is "fit to print." If the Times chose not to print anything about
column4: say
column5: Rosie O'Donnell
column6: it would be exercising its First Amendment rights
column7: just as much as it would be if it chose to print something Rosie O'Donnell doesn't like. The necessary corollary of the freedom to say/publish what one wants is the freedom to refuse to publish or say what one doesn't like. The alternative is a state-controlled press that reprints government press releases and calls them news.The question of what is or is not FoRKed is (except for libel or other specific exceptions) not a matter of law
column8: but a matter of what the "publisher" (if any) decides or the "community" (if any) negotiates or does as a matter of custom.For my part
column9: I'd rather people didn't use FoRK as a place in which to dump an expression of their political beliefs.Tom	0

column1: [ILUG] serial port transient failureHere's a weird and wacky problem:I'm currently out of the country with my trusty Evo N600c laptop. When I tried to use the serial port to talk to my mobile phone
column2: Linux behaved pretty much as if the port was fried. Bizarre
column3: I thought
column4: because I'd used it successfully while in the office. The only difference was that I was trying the thing in the hotel. I entertained brief notions of having somehow fried the serial drivers
column5: then rebooted the laptop to Windows and tried again. Worked perfectly. Back to Linux. Still not talking. Considered that it might be flaky power
column6: so I ran the laptop on battery. Nope. Tried moving the laptop to a differnet part of the room where there might be less bogon flux. Still not working. Eventually I gave up and used the IrDA port instead - which is usually the serial connection of doom
column7: grief
column8: and teeth-grinding.This morning
column9: in the office
column10: the damn thing is working without a hitch.Anyone like to suggest what mystery technology is in use in the hotel that prevents serial ports from working under Linux?Cheers

column1: /home/dudeHi
column2: some time now the following messages were haunting me:     automount[11593]: attempting to mount entry /home/dudeIt just came to my attention
column3: that only freshrpm benefitting hosts showed thisup. I grepped through the binaries and found referrences to /home/dude.# grep /home/dude /usr/bin/*Binary file /usr/bin/aaxine matchesBinary file /usr/bin/gentoo matchesBinary file /usr/bin/gphoto2 matchesBinary file /usr/bin/gtkam matches...I am now relaxed again ;)
column4: and pass this info on. Probably Matthias Saouhimself is "dude"
column5: and some package has hardwired a path in his builddirectory. It would be nice to find out which and fix it
column6: but I am using toomany of the freshrpm suite to narrow it down.Regards

column1: EnlightenmentI finally let go of my Irix Magic desktop and window managerand evaluated several other window managers. Having lost my 10 yearsof customization with my X10 and then X11 desktop at one pointat UCI
column2: I promised myself that I'd never get attached toanother WM.  I limped along in the default Gnome desktop
column3: Ihad a few unsuccessful stabs at the Solaris open view desktop
column4: but nothing really stuck.   Because of this alongwith SGI's love of pre-configured
column5: pre-compiled freeware[1]
column6: I never really made the jump from Irix to Linux either.  After installing the enlightenment WM
column7: I have to say
column8: I amreally enlightened.  It's definitely a far cry from the no frillsfirst look from previous versions.  It's only on version 0.17
column9: [2]but it's a careful balance between simplicity
column10: performance
column11: (fun) features
column12: applications
column13: and ease of customization.  Thenumber of themes they have on freshmeat is amazing. [3] Afterless than an hour or two of "nesting" I already have almostall my menus and controls setup just the way I want. I definitely recommend this to any Irix desktop holdouts.  It'sa great way to refresh your machine SGI without having to bite thebullet and rebuild it as a Linux machine. Greg[1] http://freeware.sgi.com/[2] http://www.enlightenment.org/[3] http://themes.freshmeat.net/browse/60/?topic_id=60http://xent.com/mailman/listinfo/fork	0

column1: Re: the underground software vulnerability marketplace and its    hazards (fwd)Hi Kragen
column2: This is an interesting analysis.  I think that there are a coupleof nits I might pick (for example
column3: I don't expect that the market willbe well developed with highest bidders for while)
column4: I think that themost important issue
column5: which is that end users won't be able to fixtheir systems
column6: is almost passed over.  I know that you know this
column7: andyou allude to it
column8: but your essay is getting passed around
column9: so youmight want to add to it bits about the sysadmin and others.   There's one other point which you don't make
column10: which I think is veryimportant
column11: which is that research into defining and addressing classesof vulnerabilities can't happen without libraries of availablevulnerability code.  I can think of three researchers into automatedmethods for addressing vulnerabilities who griped
column12: uninvited
column13: aboutthe quality of the existing vulnerability sites.  Doing research intoa set requires that you have enough examples
column14: in the open
column15: that youcan define a set
column16: and that the set is added to from time to time soyou can make and test predictions.   I feel fairly confident in saying that without full disclosure
column17: wewouldn't have Stackguard
column18: ITS4
column19: Nissus
column20: or snort.  And the securityadmin's job would be a lot harder.AdamOn Thu
column21: Aug 22
column24: 22 Aug 2002 00:24:54 -0400 (EDT)| From: Kragen Sitaker <kragen@pobox.com>| To: fork@spamassassin.taint.org| Subject: the underground software vulnerability marketplace and its hazards| | On August 7th
column25: an entity known as "iDEFENSE" sent out an announcement
column26: | which is appended to this email.  Briefly
column27: "iDEFENSE"
column28: which bills| itself as "a global security intelligence company"
column29: is offering cash| for information about security vulnerabilities in computer software| that are not publicly known
column30: especially if you promise not to tell| anyone else.| | If this kind of secret traffic is allowed to continue
column31: it will pose a| very serious threat to our computer communications infrastructure.| | At the moment
column32: the dominant paradigm for computer security research| known as "full disclosure"; people who discover security| vulnerabilities in software tell the vendor about them
column33: and a short| while later --- after the vendor has had a chance to fix the problem| --- they publish the information
column34: including code to exploit the| vulnerability
column35: if possible.  | | This method has proven far superior to the old paradigm established by| CERT in the late 1980s
column36: which its proponents might call "responsible| disclosure" --- never release working exploit code
column37: and never release| any information on the vulnerability before all vendors have released| a patch.  This procedure often left hundreds of thousands of computers| vulnerable to known bugs for months or years while the vendors worked| on features
column38: and often
column39: even after the patches were released
column40: people| wouldn't apply them because they didn't know how serious the problem| was.| | The underground computer criminal community would often discover and| exploit these same holes for months or years while the "responsible| disclosure" process kept their victims
column41: who had no connections in the| underground
column42: vulnerable.| | The problem with this is that vulnerabilities that are widely known| are much less dangerous
column43: because their victims can take steps to| reduce their potential impact --- including disabling software
column44: | turning off vulnerable features
column45: filtering traffic in transit
column46: and| detecting and responding to intrusions.  They are therefore much less| useful to would-be intruders.  Also
column47: software companies usually see| security vulnerabilities in their software as PR problems
column48: and so| prefer to delay publication (and the expense of fixing the bugs) as| long as possible.| | iDEFENSE is offering a new alternative that appears far more dangerous| than either of the two previous paradigms.  They want to be a buyer in| a marketplace for secret software vulnerability information
column49: rewarding| discoverers of vulnerabilities with cash.  | | Not long before
column51: a group of security researchers evidently| including some criminal elements
column52: apparently made an offer to sell the| secrecy of some software vulnerability information to the software| vendor; specifically
column53: they apparently made a private offer to| Hewlett-Packard to keep a vulnerability in HP's Tru64 Unix secret if| HP retained Snosoft's "consulting services".  HP considered this| extortion and responded with legal threats
column54: and Snosoft published the| information.| | If this is allowed to happen
column55: it will cause two problems which
column56: | together
column57: add up to a catastrophe.| | First
column58: secret software vulnerability information will be available to| the highest bidder
column59: and to nobody else.  For reasons explained later
column60: | I think the highest bidders will generally be organized crime| syndicates
column61: although that will not be obvious to the sellers.| | Second
column62: finding software vulnerabilities and keeping them secret will| become lucrative for many more talented people.  The result will be| --- just as in the "responsible disclosure" days --- that the good| guys will remain vulnerable for months and years
column63: while the majority| of current vulnerabilities are kept secret.| | I've heard it argued that the highest bidders will generally be the| vendors of the vulnerable software
column64: but I don't think that's| plausible.  If someone can steal $20 000 because a software bug lets| them
column65: the software vendor is never held liable; often
column66: in fact
column67: the| people who administer the software aren't liable
column68: either --- when| credit card data are stolen from an e-commerce site
column69: for example.| Knowing about a vulnerability before anyone else might save a web-site| administrator some time
column70: and it might save the software vendor some| negative PR
column71: but it can net the thief thousands of dollars.| | I think the highest bidders will be those for whom early vulnerability| information is most lucrative --- the thieves who can use it to| execute the largest heists without getting caught.  Inevitably
column72: that| means organized crime syndicates
column73: although the particular gangs who| are good at networked theft may not yet exist.| | There might be the occasional case where a market leader
column74: such as| Microsoft
column75: could make more money by giving their competitors bad PR| than a gang could make by theft.  Think of a remote-root hole in| Samba
column76: for example.| | Right now
column77: people who know how to find security exploits are either| motivated by personal interest in the subject
column78: motivated by the public| interest
column79: motivated by a desire for individual recognition
column80: or| personally know criminals that benefit from their exploits.  Creating| a marketplace in secret vulnerability information would vastly| increase the availability of that information to the people who can| afford to pay the most for it: spies
column81: terrorists
column82: and organized crime.| | Let's not let that happen.| | | | | This is the original iDEFENSE announcement:| | From: Sunil James [mailto:SJames@iDefense.com]| Sent: Wednesday
column83: August 07
column84: 2002 12:32 PM| Subject: Introducing iDEFENSE's Vulnerability Contributor Program| | | Greetings
column85: | | iDEFENSE is pleased to announce the official launch of its Vulnerability| Contributor Program (VCP). The VCP pays contributors for the advance| notification of vulnerabilities
column86: exploit code and malicious code.| | iDEFENSE hopes you might consider contributing to the VCP. The following| provides answers to some basic questions about the program:| | Q. How will it work?| A. iDEFENSE understands the majority of security researchers do not publish| security research for compensation; rather
column87: it could be for any of a number| of motivations
column88: including the following:| |          * Pure love of security research|          * The desire to protect against harm to targeted networks|          * The desire to urge vendors to fix their products|          * The publicity that often accompanies disclosure| | The VCP is for those who want to have their research made public to the| Internet community
column89: but who would also like to be paid for doing the| work.The compensation will depend
column90: among other things
column91: on the following| items:| |          * The kind of information being shared (i.e. vulnerability or exploit)|          * The amount of detail and analysis provided|          * The potential severity level for the information shared|          * The types of applications
column92: operating systems
column93: and other|            software and hardware potentially affected|          * Verification by iDEFENSE Labs|          * The level of exclusivity
column94: if any
column95: for data granted to iDEFENSE| | Q. Who should contribute to the VCP?| A. The VCP is open to any individual
column96: security research group or other| entity.| | Q. Why are you launching this program?| A. Timeliness remains a key aspect in security intelligence. Contributions| to some lists take time before publication to the public at large. More| often
column97: many of these services charge clients for access without paying the| original contributor. Under the iDEFENSE program
column99: iDEFENSE Labs verifies the issue
column100: and iDEFENSE clients and the| public at large are warned in a timely manner.| | Q. Who gets the credit?| A. The contributor is always credited for discovering the vulnerability or| exploit information.| | Q. When can I contribute?| The VCP is active. You are welcome to begin contributing today.| | To learn more
column101: go to http://www.idefense.com/contributor.html. If you have| questions or would like to sign up as a contributor to the VCP
column102: please| contact us at contributor@idefense.com.| | Regards
column103: | | Sunil James| Technical Analyst| iDEFENSE| | "iDEFENSE is a global security intelligence company that proactively| monitors sources throughout the world -- from technical vulnerabilities and| hacker profiling to the global spread of viruses and other malicious code.| The iALERT security intelligence service provides decision-makers
column104: frontline| security professionals and network administrators with timely access to| actionable intelligence and decision support on cyber-related threats.| iDEFENSE Labs is the research wing that verifies vulnerabilities

column1: Hanson's Sept 11 message in the National Reviewhttp://www.nationalreview.com/hanson/hanson091102.aspSeptember 11
column2: 2002 8:00 a.m.The Wages of September 11There is no going back.September 11 changed our world. Those who deny such a watershed event take asuperficially short-term view
column3: and seem to think all is as before simplybecause the sun still rises and sets.This is a colossal misjudgment. The collapse of the towers
column4: the crashinginto the Pentagon
column5: and the murder of 3
column6: 000 Americans  all seen live in realtime by millions the world over  tore off a scab and exposed deep wounds
column7: which
column8: if and when they heal
column9: will leave ugly scars for decades. The killersdealt in icons  the choice of 911 as the date of death
column10: targeting themanifest symbols of global capitalism and American military power
column11: andcentering their destruction on the largest Jewish city in the world. Yes
column12: they got their symbols in spades
column13: but they have no idea that their killinghas instead become emblematic of changes that they could scarcely imagine.Islamic fundamentalism has proved not ascendant
column14: but static
column15: morallyrepugnant  and the worst plague upon the Arab world since the Crusades. Bylurking in the shadows and killing incrementally through stealth
column16: thevampirish terrorists garnered bribes and subsidies through threats andbombs; but pale and wrinkled in the daylight after 9/11
column17: they prove onlyghoulish not fearsome.The more the world knows of al Qaeda and bin Laden
column18: the more it has foundthem both vile and yet banal  and so is confident and eager to eradicatethem and all they stand for. It is one thing to kill innocents
column19: quiteanother to take on the armed might of an aroused United States. Easilydodging a solo cruise missile in the vastness of Afghanistan may make goodtheater and bring about braggadocio; dealing with grim American and Britishcommandos who have come 7
column20: 000 miles for your head prompts abject flight andan occasional cheap infomercial on the run. And the ultimate consequence ofthe attacks of September 11 will not merely be the destruction of al Qaeda
column21: but also the complete repudiation of the Taliban
column22: the Iranian mullocracy
column23: the plague of the Pakistani madrassas
column24: and any other would-be fundamentalistparadise on earth.Foreign relations will not be the same in our generation. Our coalition withEurope
column25: we learn
column26: was not a partnership
column27: but more mere alphabeticnomenclature and the mutual back scratching of Euro-American globetrotters a paper alliance without a mission nearly 15 years after the end of the ColdWar. The truth is that Europe
column28: out of noble purposes
column29: for a decade hasinsidiously eroded its collective national sovereignty in order to craft anantidemocratic EU
column31: 000-person fuzzy bureaucracy whose executive poweris as militarily weak as it is morally ambiguous in its reliance on oftendubious international accords. This sad realization September 11 brutallyexposed
column32: and we all should cry for the beloved continent that has for themoment completely lost its moral bearings. Indeed
column33: as the months progressedthe problems inherent in "the European way" became all too apparent:pretentious utopian manifestos in lieu of military resoluteness
column34: abstractmoralizing to excuse dereliction of concrete ethical responsibility
column35: andconstant American ankle-biting even as Europe lives in a make-believe Shirewhile we keep back the forces of Mordor from its picturesque borders
column36: withonly a few brave Frodos and Bilbos tagging along. Nothing has proved moresobering to Americans than the skepticism of these blinkered Europeanhobbits after September 11.America learned that "moderate" Arab countries are as dangerous as hostileIslamic nations. After September 11
column37: being a Saudi
column38: Egyptian
column39: or Kuwaitimeans nothing special to an American  at least not proof of being any morefriendly or hostile than having Libyan
column40: Syrian
column41: or Lebanese citizenship.Indeed
column42: our entire postwar policy of propping up autocracies on the triad oftheir anticommunism
column43: oil
column44: and arms purchases  like NATO  belongs to apre-9/11 age of Soviet aggrandizement and petroleum monopolies. Now we learnthat broadcasting state-sponsored hatred of Israel and the United States isjust as deadly to our interests as scud missiles  and as likely to comefrom friends as enemies. Worst-case scenarios like Iran and Afghanistanoffer more long-term hope than "stable regimes" like the Saudis; governmentsthat hate us have populations that like us  and vice versa; the Saudi royalfamily
column45: whom 5
column46: 000 American troops protect
column47: and the Mubarak autocracy
column48: whichhas snagged billions of American dollars
column49: are as afraid of democraticreformers as they are Islamic fundamentalists. And with good reason: Islamicgovernments in Iran and under the Taliban were as hated by the masses asArab secular reformers in exile in the West are praised and championed.The post-9/11 domestic calculus is just as confusing. Generals and themilitary brass call civilians who seek the liberation of Iraq "chickenhawks" and worse. Yet such traditional Vietnam-era invective I think ringshollow after September 11
column50: and sounds more like McClellan's shrillnessagainst his civilian overseers who precipitously wanted an odious slaveryended than resonant of Patton's audacity in charging after murderous Nazis.More Americans were destroyed at work in a single day than all thosesoldiers killed in enemy action since the evacuation of Vietnam nearly 30years ago. Indeed
column51: most troops who went through the ghastly inferno ofVietnam are now in or nearing retirement; and
column52: thank God
column53: there is nogeneration of Americans in the present military  other than a few thousandbrave veterans of the Gulf
column54: Mogadishu
column55: and Panama  who have been insustained and deadly shooting with heavy casualties. Because Americansoldiers and their equipment are as impressive as our own domestic securityis lax
column56: in this gruesome war it may well be more perilous to work high up inlower Manhattan
column57: fly regularly on a jumbo jet
column58: or handle mail at thePentagon or CIA than be at sea on a sub or destroyer.Real concern for the sanctity of life may hinge on employing rather thanrejecting force
column59: inasmuch as our troops are as deadly and protected abroadas our women
column60: children
column61: aged
column62: and civilians are impotent and vulnerable athome. It seems to me a more moral gamble to send hundreds of pilots intoharm's way than allow a madman to further his plots to blow up or infectthousands in high-rises.Politics have been turned upside down. In the old days
column63: cynicalconservatives were forced to hold their noses and to practice a sometimesrepellent Realpolitik. In the age of Russian expansionism
column64: they were loatheto champion democracy when it might usher in a socialist Trojan Horse whosebelly harbored totalitarians disguised as parliamentarians. Thus they wereso often at loggerheads with nave and idealist leftists.No longer. The end of the specter of a deadly and aggressive SovietCommunism has revived democratic ideology as a force in diplomacy. Championsof freedom no longer sigh and back opportunistic rightist thugs who promiseopen economics
column65: loot their treasuries
column66: and keep out the Russians. Instead
column67: even reactionaries are now more likely to push for democratic governments inthe Middle East than are dour and skeptical leftists. The latter
column68: ifmulticulturalists
column69: often believe that democracy is a value-neutral Westernconstruct
column70: not necessarily a universal good; if pacifists
column71: they claimnonintervention
column72: not justice
column73: as their first priority. The Right
column74: not theLeft
column75: now is the greater proponent of global freedom
column76: liberation
column77: andidealism  with obvious domestic ramifications for any Republican presidentastute enough to tap that rich vein of popular support.All this and more are the wages of the disaster of September 11 and thesubsequent terrible year  and yet it is likely that
column78: for good or evil
column79: wewill see things even more incredible in the twelve months ahead.	0
